html: 2.20.19  6:13 pm   1.1.18 1:34 pm hey so. i know these days it's mostly good for naming what notes you have in your scale BUT also there is a way to think of modes where you can use it to go wild and crazy deciding what chords sound good with your melody in what order, cause why does a 5 chord have to be major or. to think sideways about it if we're in C why does the 1 chord have to be the one you go to for resting and resolution what if we always come back to a major 4 chord instead of 1. what if we're really in lydian so everything that sounds like 4 is 1. for example https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ov-OAmpcRfw is lydian it doesn't even have any accidentals anywhere it's like the music is hanging from some wings it grew on its way to the next universe

html:
2.20.19  2:38 pm   Bill, I'd love your thoughts on this. From your experience, what's your opinion on inspiration?

      Do you only work when you're "inspired" (whatever that means for you)

      or do you sit down to work even when you don't have particularly inspirational ideas and build them as you go? There seems to be this whole thing built up around inspiration and we even have the word "eureka" and everyone knows how the apple dropped on Newton's head or how Paul heard "Yesterday" in his sleep etc. On the other hand, many artists say that they work on a schedule (like you) and that seems to work too. Steven King says he writes 6 pages every day. So either he has an inexhaustible well of inspiration hidden somewhere or he doesn't need inspiration all the time to make progress on his books.
original_html:
2.20.19  2:38 pm   Bill, I'd love your thoughts on this. From your experience, what's your opinion on inspiration?

      Do you only work when you're "inspired" (whatever that means for you)

      or do you sit down to work even when you don't have particularly inspirational ideas and build them as you go? There seems to be this whole thing built up around inspiration and we even have the word "eureka" and everyone knows how the apple dropped on Newton's head or how Paul heard "Yesterday" in his sleep etc. On the other hand, many artists say that they work on a schedule (like you) and that seems to work too. Steven King says he writes 6 pages every day. So either he has an inexhaustible well of inspiration hidden somewhere or he doesn't need inspiration all the time to make progress on his books.
